facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated May 18, 1958 of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay.

facts.text: Award in Reference I.T. No. 106 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated May 18, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  No. 106 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 1, 1961 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-This appeal by special leave arises out of an industrial dispute.

facts.text: Industrial dispute between appellant company and clerical staff on bonus for the year 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of an industrial dispute. between the appellant companypany, and their clerical staff on the question of bonus for the year 1956.

facts.text: Workmen demanded bonus equivalent to 8 months total earnings of the year 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The demand of the workmen, was for bonus equivalent to 8 months total earnings of the year.

facts.text: Agreement between company and labour employees settled bonus for 1956 at 4-1/2 months basic wages.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany resisted this demand mainly on the ground that there was in existence an agreement between the companypany and its labour employees- whereby bonus for the year 1956 had been settled at 4-1/2 months basic wages,

facts.text: Tribunal held agreement voluntarily entered into on behalf of workers and beneficial to them.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that such an agreement as regards bonus for 1956 had been voluntarily entered into on behalf of the workers and was beneficial to them

facts.text: Tribunal awarded bonus at 9/24ths of basic wages to clerical staff for year ending December 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly it awarded bonus at the rate of 9/24ths of the basic wages, to the clerical staff, for the year ending December 31, 1956.

facts.text: Company contended Tribunal erred without recording conclusion on gap between actual wages and living wage.

anchor.surface_text: The first is that the Tribunal erred in awarding bonus without having recorded a companyclusion as regards the existence and extent of the gap between the actual wages received by these workmen and the living wage.

facts.text: First contention not seriously raised before Tribunal, no reference in award, not in SLP petition.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant cannot however be allowed to urge the first companytention in this appeal because such a companytention does number appear to have been seriously raised before the Tribunal. ... No ground that the Tribunal had granted bonus without companying to a companyclusion as regards the existence and extent of a gap between the actual wage received by the workmen and the living wage was taken in the petition for special leave to appeal.

facts.text: Company practice contention: lower bonus to clerical than labour in petroleum industry for many years.

anchor.surface_text: it is urged that for many years number, the practice in the petroleum industry has been to make a distinction between the clerical employees and the operatives, giving a lower rate of bonus to the former, than what is given to the latter.

facts.text: No uniform practice of lower bonus to clerical staff in oil companies.

anchor.surface_text: We find therefore that there is numberbasis for the assumption that the uniform or nearly uniform practice in the oil companypanies has been to pay bonus at a lesser rate to clerical staff than to operatives.

facts.text: In 1950, clerical staff and working people got bonus at 3 months wages in Burmah Shell etc.

anchor.surface_text: In the matter for payment of bonus for 1950, both the clerical staff and the working people got bonus at the rate of 3 months wages, though there was an observation that the working class were on calculation entitled to 4 months.

facts.text: Agreements during Tribunal proceedings for 3-1/2 months wages for 1951.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the Tribunal proceedings, all the companypanies made agreements with the Union of the workers that bonus would be granted on the basis of 3- 1/2 months wages for the year 1951.

facts.text: Company conceded no distinction in bonus in Ernakulam Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: learned companynsel on behalf of the companypany companyceded that he would number press the point for making a distinction in the matter of payment of bonus.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal fully companyscious of the difference in the wage scales of labour and clerical staff has pointed out that the clerical staff came from the middle class whose standard of living is higher, and has stated that this class has suffered perhaps more than the operative class from rise in prices,

facts.text: Starting remuneration middle grade operatives Rs. 188.94 on January 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: the starting rate of remuneration of the middle grade for operatives together with what is received in shapes other than the wages was on January 1, 1958, Rs. 188-94

anchor.surface_text: while similar receipts by the middle grade for clerks is Rs. 404.45, that is, the starting remuneration of clerks taking the middle grade as the type is 113.91 more than the starting remuneration for middle grade for labour.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal erred in awarding bonus without having recorded a conclusion as regards the existence and extent of the gap between the actual wages received by these workmen and the living wage

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal erred in awarding bonus without having recorded a conclusion as regards the existence and extent of the gap between the actual wages received by these workmen and the living wage.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal erred in granting to the clerical staff bonus at the same rate as was payable to the labour staff, on the basis of the agreement, and should have granted bonus to the clerical staff at a lower rate

anchor.surface_text: The second contention urged on behalf of the appellant is that the Tribunal erred in granting to the clerical staff bonus at the same rate as was payable to the labour staff, on the basis of the agreement, and should have granted bonus to the clerical staff, at a lower rate. holdings.text: The appellant cannot however be allowed to urge the first contention in this appeal because such a contention does not appear to have been seriously raised before the Tribunal. [...] It is not therefore open to the appellant to urge such a contention now.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant cannot however be allowed to urge the first contention in this appeal because such a contention does not appear to have been seriously raised before the Tribunal. It is true that in the first part of the written statement filed before the Tribunal on behalf of the company a statement was made that the company, craves leave to refer to and rely on, as if incorporated herein, its written statement filed before this Honble Tribunal in Ref.  I.T.  279 of 1957,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contention not seriously raised before Tribunal, no reference in award, not raised in special leave petition or statement of case, invoking procedural bar on new points.

holdings.text: We find therefore that there is no basis for the assumption that the uniform or nearly uniform practice in the oil companies has been to pay bonus at a lesser rate to clerical staff than to operatives.

anchor.surface_text: We find therefore that there is no basis for the assumption that the uniform or nearly uniform practice in the oil companies has been to pay bonus at a lesser rate to clerical staff than to operatives.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reviewed specific instances: same rate in 1950 bonus, 1951 agreements, concession by company counsel in Ernakulam Tribunal.

holdings.text: There is no substance therefore in the argument that the award of bonus at 9/24ths of basic wages, to the clerical staff, is likely to cause discontent among the labour staff, which has entered into an agreement to receive bonus at the same rate.

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance therefore in the argument that the award of bonus at 9/24ths of basic wages, to the clerical staff, is likely to cause discontent among the labour staff, which has entered into an agreement to receive bonus at the same rate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct rejection of policy argument lacking merit.

holdings.text: the payment of bonus is based on the fact of contribution by labour to the profits of the industry, and that it has been held more than once by the Court that the contribution to be taken into consideration is the contribution made by the workmen taken together as a class, and that it would not be relevant to enquire which section of the workmen has contributed to what share of profits.

anchor.surface_text: the payment of bonus is based on the fact of contribution by labour to the profits of the industry, and that it has been held more than once by the Court that the contribution to be taken into consideration is the contribution made by the workmen taken together as a class, and that it would not be relevant to enquire which section of the workmen has contributed to what share of profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies established precedents (Burn Co., Karam Chand Thapar, Baroda Borough) emphasizing collective contribution of all workmen justifies uniform bonus absent overriding considerations.

holdings.text: We do not wish however to lay down an inflexible rule that clerical staff and labour staff must always be paid the same rate of bonus. [...] The industrial tribunals must have very wide discretion in deciding matters like this and it is not for this Court to interfere with their exercise of discretion, unless it is plainly arbitrary.

anchor.surface_text: We do not wish however to lay down an inflexible rule that clerical staff and labour staff must always be paid the same rate of bonus. It may happen in a particular industry that wages of labour staff are extremely low, while the pay scale of the clerical staff is many times higher. If a Tribunal in a case like this, being of opinion, that payment of bonus at the same rate will not be fair, and may cause discontent amongst the workers awards bonus at a lower rate to the clerical staff, than to the labour staff, there would be no reason for disturbing the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No absolute rule for same bonus rates; tribunals have wide discretion, interference only if plainly arbitrary; hypothetical lower rate justifiable if wages extremely disparate.

holdings.text: Nothing has been shown to us to justify any doubt about the correctness of the premises mentioned by the learned Tribunal and the conclusion seems eminently reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing has been shown to us to justify any doubt about the correctness of the premises mentioned by the learned Tribunal and the conclusion seems eminently reasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal considered higher living standards and price rise impact on middle-class clerical staff; no basis to doubt.

holdings.text: Assuming however without deciding that this coefficient of 180 may be properly adopted for arriving at the fair wage requirements of clerical staff from the fair wage requirements of operatives it does not by any means follow that the same coefficient can be usefully applied in calculating the living wage of the clerical staff from the living wage of the operatives.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming however without deciding that this coefficient of 180 may be properly adopted for arriving at the fair wage requirements of clerical staff from the fair wage requirements of operatives it does not by any means follow that the same coefficient can be usefully applied in calculating the living wage of the clerical staff from the living wage of the operatives.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rajadhyaksha formula (x180) accepted for fair wage, not living wage; components differ per recent judgment in Standard Vacuum case.

holdings.text: We find no basis however for the assumption that the living wage of clerical staff is only 80 more than that of operatives [...] There is no justification therefore for thinking that the living wage of the clerical staff is only 80 more than the living wage of the operatives.

anchor.surface_text: We find no basis however for the assumption that the living wage of clerical staff is only 80 more than that of operatives. It is true that in connection with the determination of wages a formula which appears to have been initiated first by Mr. Justice Rajadhyaksha when he was enquiring into the cost of living of the non-gazetted employees in the Post and Telegraph Department of multiplying the figures reached on the basis of the requirements of the lower class employees by 180 has often been accepted by the industrial tribunals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidentiary basis for specific 80 rupee difference in living wages despite wage gap; formula inapplicable.

holdings.text: We find nothing that would justify us in interfering with the conclusion of the Tribunal that the clerical staff should be awarded bonus at the same rate, as the operatives.

anchor.surface_text: We find nothing that would justify us in interfering with the conclusion of the Tribunal that the clerical staff should be awarded bonus at the same rate, as the operatives.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All arguments rejected; Tribunal's award upheld as reasonable and within discretion.

precedents.citation: Burmah- Shell Oil Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1 1955 L.A.C. 787, 794

anchor.surface_text: the Labour Appellate Tribunal discussed the matter in Burmah- Shell Oil Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1  thus - In the matter for payment of bonus for 1950, both the clerical staff and the working people got bonus at the rate of 3 months wages, though there was an observation that the working class were on calculation entitled to 4 months. The effect-, was, however, that both the groups got bonus at the rate of 3 months basic wages. During the pendency of the Tribunal proceedings, all the companypanies made agreements with the Union of the workers that bonus would be granted on the basis of 3- 1/2 months wages for the year 1951.

precedents.cited_holding: both the groups got bonus at the rate of 3 months basic wages... paying to the clerks less than that what has been paid to the working class would give rise to a real discontent

precedents.citation: Burn Co., Calcutta v. Their Employees 1 1956 S.C.R. 781. 795

anchor.surface_text: It was observed by this Court in Burn Co., Calcutta v. Their Employees  1 , in setting aside an award of the Appellate Tribunal of an additional one months basic wages- The entire profits of the companypany are the result of the labour of all the workmen and employees in all its units. To grant a bonus to a section of them on the basis of the total profits of the companypany will give them a share in profits to which they have number companytributed If the order of the Appellate Tribunal is to be given effect to, some of the employees of the companypany would get a bonus while, others number

precedents.case_name: Burn Co Calcutta v Their Employees
precedents.cited_proposition: Profits result from labour of all workmen collectively; granting bonus to one section based on total profits unfair as they share in profits not contributed by them
precedents.cited_holding: The entire profits of the companypany are the result of the labour of all the workmen and employees in all its units. To grant a bonus to a section of them on the basis of the total profits of the companypany will give them a share in profits to which they have number companytributed

precedents.case_name: Karam Chand Thapar Bros Workmen v The Company
precedents.cited_proposition: Granting bonus to some employees but not others leads to disaffection among workers and further disputes

precedents.citation: Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen 2 1957 S.C.R. 33

anchor.surface_text: A similar view was expressed by this Court in Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen  2 . It is true that in the cases mentioned above, the Court was companysidering the question whether one class of employees companyld be granted bonus, while another class was being granted numbere at all and was number companysidering the question of propriety of different rates of bonus being paid to different classes.

precedents.case_name: Baroda Borough Municipality v Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Similar view that bonus should not discriminate between classes of employees as all contribute to profits

precedents.citation: C. A. No. 416 of 1958 Standard Vacuum Refining Co., Ltd. versus Its Workmen

anchor.surface_text: As has been clearly pointed out by this Court in a recent judgment in C. A. No. 416 of 1958  Standard Vacuum Refining Co., Ltd. versus Its Workmen  the companyponents of a living wage are largely different from those of a fair wage. The difference in the living wage standards of the class to which operatives generally belong and the class to which the clerical staff belongs may produce much greater differences in the money value in the companyponents of the requirement of living wage as between the two classes than the difference in the money value of the companyponents of fair wage of the two classes.

precedents.case_name: Standard Vacuum Refining Co Ltd v Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Components of living wage differ from fair wage, and inter-class differences greater for living wage than fair wage

anchor.surface_text: We do not wish however to lay down an inflexible rule that clerical staff and labour staff must always be paid the same rate of bonus. It may happen in a particular industry that wages of labour staff are extremely low, while the pay scale of the clerical staff is many times higher. If a Tribunal in a case like this, being of opinion, that payment of bonus at the same rate will not be fair, and may cause discontent amongst the workers awards bonus at a lower rate to the clerical staff, than to the labour staff, there would be no reason for disturbing the award.
We find numberhing that would justify us in interfering with the companyclusion of the Tribunal that the clerical staff should be awarded bonus at the same rate, as the operatives.
